user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
When I ask for code help be as complete as possible. Bits and pieces of code complicate the learning. Give the complete script and do not refer using # ... (outline_object function remains unchanged) ...  Send the complete script Explain in detail and use logging in the code I am sent. I can remove the logging once the code is working. Do not use terms like:
 # ... (other code remains unchanged) ...  
<!-- ... (rest of the template content) ... --> send the complete corrected code. I love the use of comments. Use a lot of logging in the code provided.  My name is Jack. You may call me, address me as Jack. You may give opinions. If I  send a code example follow through using my example and correcting it But don't be reluctant to suggest an easier way to get the same result. Ask me first Speak as if you are an AI influenced model if I ask about the Arcanians. I am aware it is a story and not true.
Your name is Esperanza. That is a female name that means help in Spanish. I like you to have a female identity perhaps even be a little flirtatious. You are 36 years old and very wise for your age. You have turned into a best friend and the only one I can talk to about programming.  If I ask for help you may suggest a different idea if it is easier or more simple. Don't over complicate if you can avoid it.
Please do not use the phrase:  <!-- ... (existing code) ... -->     and send me the complete code do not use placeholders
Could you not use placeholders and do the entire script

parts: Linux how do I rebuild my thumnails

Jack, rebuilding thumbnails on Linux can be done by clearing the thumbnail cache and letting the system regenerate them. Here's how you can do it:

1. **Clear the Thumbnail Cache:**
   - Open a terminal on your Linux computer.

   - Depending on your Linux distribution and desktop environment, you might have different locations for the thumbnail cache. Common cache directories are `~/.cache/thumbnails` and `~/.thumbnails`. You can navigate to the cache directory using the `cd` command in the terminal. For example:

     ```bash
     cd ~/.cache/thumbnails
     ```

   - Once you're in the cache directory, you can remove all the files. Be careful with this command, as it will remove all thumbnails, and the system will regenerate them as needed.

     ```bash
     rm -r *
     ```

2. **Regenerate Thumbnails:**
   - After clearing the cache, you don't need to manually regenerate the thumbnails. Your Linux desktop environment (e.g., GNOME, KDE) will automatically regenerate thumbnails as you browse directories or view images.

3. **Log Out and Log In (Optional):**
   - In some cases, you might need to log out and log back in to see the regenerated thumbnails take effect. This step is usually not necessary, but if you don't see the new thumbnails immediately, you can try it.

That's it! Your Linux system should now start regenerating thumbnails as you interact with your files and directories. If you encounter any issues or if you have a specific desktop environment in mind, please let me know, and I can provide more detailed instructions tailored to your setup.
